author: By Rebecca Smith
title: The English Countryside Is a Place of Profound Inequality
description: My childhood was spent in the corners of landscaped gardens at a grand country estate. But they weren’t my gardens.
content: Often people assume I am someone I am not. My childhood was spent making dens in the hidden corners of the landscaped gardens of a grand country estate in the Lake District. I wandered woods full of baby pheasants being fattened up for the shoot. I roamed the hills listening to my Walkman like a modern Brontë sister. I had lakes to paddle in and a dinghy that we bumped down the ­path to a private beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: A Vanishing Masterpiece in the Georgia Marshes
description: An essential American outdoor sculpture has been sinking in the saltwater marsh for four decades — just as the artist, Beverly Buchanan, intended.
content: This patch of coastal wetland between highway and marsh, just behind downtown Brunswick, Ga., is a kind of pilgrimage site — though no sign points to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein
title: Reluctant to Retire, Leaders Raise a Tough Question: How Old Is Too Old?
description: Two troubling moments involving Senators Dianne Feinstein and Mitch McConnell thrust questions about aging in office out of Congress and into the national conversation.
content: After a series of troubling moments this week, an uncomfortable question has become unavoidable, leaving voters, strategists and even politicians themselves wondering: Just how old is too old to serve in public office?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Worms Revived After 46,000 Years Frozen in Siberian Permafrost
description: Scientists want to understand how the worms survived in extreme conditions for extraordinarily long periods of time.
content: At a time when the mighty woolly mammoth roamed the Earth, some 46,000 years ago, a minuscule pair of roundworms became encased in the Siberian permafrost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Command for Attention
description: Sam Ezersky’s themeless grid has a glow to it.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I imagine that regular weekend solvers of the New York Times Crossword will agree with me when I say that this grid from Sam Ezersky is a bit of a breather after a multiyear run of infernally challenging themeless puzzles. It still makes for a workout, with many debuts (12 total, some quite oddball) and a spritz of wordplay, including the puzzle’s two brilliant bookends at 1-Across (its seed entry) and 58-Across.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron M. Kinzer
title: The Joy of Driving, After 12 Years in Prison
description: He once made a living behind the wheel. Now, the road suggests fresh possibilities.
content: On a cool April morning, my mother pulled up outside the halfway house in Augusta, Ga., where I had been living since my release from federal prison. She was one of the few people who had supported me during my years behind bars. I sat in the passenger’s seat of the black Ford Fusion as she drove to the DMV, where I was scheduled to obtain a new driver’s license.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas, Jazmine Ulloa and Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump, Spared Attacks by Rivals in Iowa, Doesn’t Return the Favor
description: Almost every one of former President Trump’s 13 rivals who attended the dinner declined to even mention the primary’s front-runner.
content: Candidate after candidate at an Iowa Republican dinner on Friday avoided so much as mentioning the dominant front-runner in the race, former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Rep. Dean Phillips Says He Is Considering a Run Against Biden
description: Mr. Phillips, a Minnesota Democrat, has received attention for his outspoken calls for aging members of the Democratic Party to step aside.
content: Representative Dean Phillips, a Minnesota Democrat who has for months been saying in public what many in his party only whisper in private — that the 80-year-old President Biden should not seek re-election because of his age — said he was considering challenging Mr. Biden in next year’s primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Australia to Fast-Track Missile Production for U.S. Exports
description: The announcement of this plan, along with steps to expand joint military exercises, was shadowed by the news of a helicopter crash during one such exercise.
content: Australia will accelerate efforts to make missiles for the United States as well as expand military cooperation and training under a plan announced on Saturday by Australian and American officials. The announcement came as the two countries paused a joint military exercise to search for the four-person crew of an Australian army helicopter that crashed overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Treat Loneliness (and Should We?)
description: Readers offer their suggestions, including group therapy and psychedelics, but also question the need for solutions.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: ‘A Dangerous Combination’: Teenagers’ Accidents Expose E-Bike Risks
description: The e-bike industry is booming, but many vehicles are not legal for teenagers, and accidents are on the rise.
content: On a Thursday evening in late June, Clarissa Champlain learned that her 15-year-old son Brodee had been in a terrible crash, the latest teen victim of an e-bike accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Sinead O’Connor, Prince and the Thrill of ‘Nothing Compares 2 U’
description: O’Connor, who was found dead this week, was catapulted to fame when she covered the song written by Prince on her sophomore album.
content: Sinead O’Connor and Prince, passionate singer-songwriters who both died in their mid-50s, were tied together by the plaintive song “Nothing Compares 2 U,” which catapulted O’Connor to fame when she recorded it for her sophomore album.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Savannah DeMelo’s World Cup Trial by Fire
description: DeMelo had never played for the United States women’s team when she was named to the World Cup roster. Thrust into a starting role, she’s doing her best to fit in.
content: Savannah DeMelo said the reality that she was playing for the United States in the Women’s World Cup finally hit her as the fans in the stadium counted down the final 10 seconds before her first match. She only started to get truly comfortable, though, once people starting kicking her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My 55+ Community Is Discriminating Against Me. What Power Do I Have?
description: Start with the house rules, then consider getting a lawyer involved.
content: Q: My husband and I own a condo in a 55-plus community on Long Island. He likes to golf, while I like to use the complex’s outdoor pool. Our homeowners association just made a rule that single owners can bring a guest to the pool, but married couples have to bring their spouse, or no one at all. The rule allows single owners to bring guests as young as 16 years old. I would like to bring my daughter or my sister, but the board has denied my request. We all pay the same HOA fees. Can I do anything about this policy? Isn’t this discrimination against married couples?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler, Bernhard Warner and Ephrat Livni
title: After Affirmative Action Ruling, Legacy Admissions Take Center Stage
description: Schools have financial incentives to favor the relatives of alumni.
content: If colleges do away with legacy admissions, will it cost them financially? That’s the big question being whispered among university provosts and trustees across the country as the practice of giving children of alumni an edge in admissions comes under fire and there is increasing pressure to end it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Back in the Saddle and Out on the Water
description: A critic recommends old and new titles.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Coast to Coast, a Corridor of Coups Brings Turmoil in Africa
description: This past week’s military takeover in Niger completed a domino chain of countries ruled by leaders who seized power by force, fueling instability and presenting a conundrum for the United States.
content: Africa’s coup belt spans the continent: a line of six countries crossing 3,500 miles, from coast to coast, that has become the longest corridor of military rule on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
title: A Sense of Mission at Risk as Israeli Reservists Resign to Protest New Law
description: Military reservists are key to Israel’s defense capacity and a shared sense of national mission. But scores of reservists have resigned over a new law curbing judicial power, reflecting a widening rift in Israeli society.
content: For 33 years, Eitan Herzel has proudly dovetailed his career in Israel’s vaunted tech industry with reserve duty in an elite commando unit of the Israeli military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Nobody Ever Read American Literature Like This Guy Did
description: Inflamed, impertinent and deeply insightful, D.H. Lawrence’s “Studies in Classic American Literature” remains startlingly relevant 100 years after it was originally published.
content: It has been a hundred years since D.H. Lawrence published “Studies in Classic American Literature,” and in the annals of literary criticism the book may still claim the widest discrepancy between title and content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: A Summer Spectacle Where Fireflies Are the Guiding Light
description: Bill and Mary-Ellen McDonald host firefly viewing parties, hoping to inspire their neighbors to stop using pesticides and consider rewilding their lawns.
content: New Canaan, a wealthy town in Connecticut, is a town of lawns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: ‘If You Don’t Do Anything You Feel Like a Criminal’
description: The work of conflict journalism is now more dangerous than ever. Does it still serve a purpose?
content: We are living in the most thoroughly documented time in human existence. There are billions of us carrying cameras in our pockets, and the videos we make ricochet across the internet with astonishing ease: silly things, like dance moves and pratfalls, along with deadly serious things, like police officers murdering unarmed civilians or children choking on chemical weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald, Matt Joycey and Ben Laffin
title: Canada Is Ravaged by Fire. No One Has Paid More Dearly Than Indigenous People.
description: The country’s record-breaking fire season has led tens of thousands of Indigenous people to flee their homes and ravaged forests they rely on for sustenance.
content: In early July, fierce wildfires fueled by dry conditions in northern Quebec laid waste to large swaths of spruce forest, destroying cabins and tourist camps. It also cut off transportation to isolated Indigenous communities over the region’s lone paved road, a 370-mile stretch of highway with little or no cell reception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: In Border Towns, a ‘Dangerous Combination’ of Heat and Water Cutoffs
description: Trying to keep cool during a record-setting summer is a social divide for residents of low-income colonias, where running water can be in short supply.
content: On a blistering morning this week, the kitchen sink in Kathy Quilatan’s house was delivering only sputtering water. With temperatures climbing into triple digits most afternoons these days, she knew exactly what she had to do to keep her two young children, ages 2 and 6, from overheating. She gathered several plastic containers and set out on a quest for water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: After $700 Million U.S. Bailout, Trucking Firm Is Shutting Down
description: Yellow, which received a pandemic loan, is winding down operations ahead of an expected bankruptcy filing. The closure of the company would mean the loss of about 30,000 jobs.
content: Yellow, the beleaguered trucking company that received a $700 million pandemic loan from the federal government, notified staff on Friday that it is shutting down and laying off employees at all of its locations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: It’s Been a Hellish Summer for the Mediterranean. And It’s Not Over.
description: Record heat and wildfires have turned summer holidays into nightmares and called into question the future of cherished tourist destinations.
content: As a family sat vigil over a coffin containing the body of an elderly relative, the wooded hills around their apartment building in Palermo burned from wildfires. Winds blew the blazes closer, torching cars, dumpsters, sheds and electricity poles. Then the flames licked the apartment building, forcing its inhabitants to flee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Ronen Bergman
title: Biden Presses Ahead With Effort to Broker Israeli-Saudi Rapprochement
description: The president sent Jake Sullivan, his national security adviser, on the latest diplomatic mission seeking to forge ties between Saudi Arabia and Israel.
content: President Biden’s envoys are pushing ahead with their effort to realign Middle East politics by brokering the establishment of diplomatic relations between Saudi Arabia and Israel despite significant concessions demanded by the Saudi monarchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to This American Life: I Can’t Quit You, Baby
description: One of the show’s producers tries to quit smoking.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Burkeman
title: Stop Multitasking. No, Really — Just Stop It.
description: Get comfortable with accomplishing less.
content: A few months ago, I was teetering on the brink of feeling overwhelmed by life’s responsibilities, afflicted by the ambient anxiety that seems to be an intrinsic part of life in the 2020s. In an effort to maintain — or maybe restore — my sanity, I embarked on a personal endurance challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Larson
title: For Your Broken Heart, Consider a Breakup Budget
description: We’re likely to spend more after a relationship ends. So why don’t we budget for it?
content: For a month after a breakup in early June, I wavered between empowered mania and “Wuthering Heights” anguish. If I’d had access to moors I would have roamed them nightly à la the book’s brutish, tormented hero, Heathcliff, wild-haired and sporting a messy cravat, but I was in Austin, Texas, where there is nary a moor and it’s too hot for roaming. So, as I had done after previous breakups, I dabbled in retail therapy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Fighting for Anthony: The Struggle to Save Portland, Oregon
description: The city has long grappled with street homelessness and a shortage of housing. Now fentanyl has turned a perennial problem into a deadly crisis and a challenge to the city’s progressive identity.
content: Come to Portland, his sister said. It’s green and beautiful, people are friendly and there are plenty of jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: An Internet Veteran’s Guide to Not Being Scared of Technology
description: Mike Masnick, who founded Techdirt in 1998, writes for an influential audience of lawmakers, C.E.O.s and activists. Somehow, he’s still an optimist about the promise of technology.
content: How could they protect themselves from A.I.?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump and DeSantis Collide for First Time in Iowa, as Fortunes Diverge
description: A contest once viewed as a two-man race between Donald J. Trump and Ron DeSantis has settled into a new dynamic: Mr. Trump versus everyone else.
content: When former President Donald J. Trump and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida shared the same stage at an Iowa Republican Party dinner on Friday, their appearances seemed to capture the basic dynamics of the 2024 presidential primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Colombian President’s Son Is Arrested in Money Laundering Inquiry
description: The arrest of Nicolás Petro poses another test for President Gustavo Petro, who has struggled to push many of his reforms through a divided Congress.
content: The son of Gustavo Petro, the president of Colombia, was arrested on charges of money laundering and illicit enrichment, the attorney general’s office announced early Saturday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Doing Front Flips
description: John Kugelman’s debut puzzle merrily turns and spins.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Victoria Kim
title: Russia Strikes Another Grain Terminal, Extending a Campaign Against Ukraine’s Ports
description: In St. Petersburg, President Vladimir V. Putin rejected calls for reviving a Black Sea grain deal or for ending fighting.
content: Russian forces struck a grain terminal in the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson, Ukrainian officials said on Saturday, extending a bombardment of the country’s infrastructure that has raised alarm about Kyiv’s ability to ship grain to the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 29, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 29, 2023.
content: An article on Page 1 this weekend about repurposed abandoned buildings in the Hudson Valley misidentifies the year that BjornQorn bought the Skate Time roller rink. It was 2022, not 2012.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilyssa Daly
title: In Mississippi, Open Secrets Lay in a Pile of Records
description: Accusations against the powerful sheriff in Clay County were there for anybody to find.
content: The accusations of sexual misconduct against Eddie Scott, the sheriff of Clay County, Miss., will be new to almost everyone who reads our latest investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: They Put the Heart in ‘Heartstopper’
description: Kit Connor and Joe Locke discuss the pressure of expectations and how the global success of their Netflix hit, returning Aug. 3, has changed their lives.
content: Kit Connor and Joe Locke sat on a plump bordello-red couch at the Manhattan headquarters of Netflix. It was June, and they were in town to talk about their roles as the leading sweeties on “Heartstopper,” Alice Oseman’s romantic dramedy series about queer British high schoolers that begins its sophomore season on Netflix on Aug. 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Ormont Blumberg
title: Why Are Dave Matthews Band Fans So Loyal?
description: Some have spent thousands of dollars and traveled hundreds of miles to see them since their summer tours started in the early ’90s.
content: On an afternoon in June while wildfire smoke enveloped Manhattan, people lined up outside Irving Plaza — some before dawn, some sporting face masks, some fresh off red-eye flights — to see Dave Matthews. That night, the 56-year-old balladeer was playing a rare solo gig celebrating his namesake band’s new album, “Walk Around the Moon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: School Will Pay $9.1 Million to Settle Lawsuit Over a Student’s Suicide
description: After Mallory Grossman took her own life at age 12, her parents accused her New Jersey school district of failing to respond to accusations of bullying.
content: A New Jersey school district has agreed to pay $9.1 million to the parents of a sixth grader who died by suicide in 2017, ending a lawsuit that accused administrators of failing to take bullying complaints seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Trader Joe’s Recalls Cookies and Falafel Because They ‘May Contain Rocks’
description: The California-based grocery chain issued a total of three recalls in one week over potential contaminants, including one for a broccoli cheddar soup that “may contain insects.”
content: Trader Joe’s issued three voluntary recalls this week with warnings that certain products “may contain rocks” or “may contain insects.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Ryder Howe and Nic Antaya
title: The Robots We Were Afraid of Are Already Here
description: The long-anticipated automation revolution has begun. Robots are ready to operate forklifts and do laundry. It’s not as scary as it sounds.
content: Digit drew a crowd, even here, in a convention center full of robot aficionados.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Hunts Chinese Malware That Could Disrupt American Military Operations
description: American intelligence officials believe the malware could give China the power to disrupt or slow American deployments or resupply operations, including during a Chinese move against Taiwan.
content: The Biden administration is hunting for malicious computer code it believes China has hidden deep inside the networks controlling power grids, communications systems and water supplies that feed military bases in the United States and around the world, according to American military, intelligence and national security officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The Dave Matthews Band, Reconsidered
description: When we’re young, we define ourselves as much by the culture we disdain as by what we love. One of the pleasures of adulthood is letting some of that go.
content: The Dave Matthews Band is on tour, as they have been every summer, except 2020, for the past 30-odd years. Like the Grateful Dead and Phish, so-called jam bands with which it’s often lumped together, Dave Matthews has a deliriously passionate fan base that follows the band from city to city, reuniting with fellow disciples at preshow tailgates, showing off devotional tattoos, trading live recordings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Creator of a Women-Centric Whiskey Brand Spends Her Sundays
description: Kate Rosante, who co-founded the bourbon company Boss Molly, makes themed cocktails for movie nights at her summer house in Amagansett.
content: Kate Rosante’s passion for cocktails is thanks to her father, who built a bar in the living room of her childhood home. “I loved gathering around the guests and fetching drinks,” said Ms. Rosante, 43, a co-founder of the bourbon brand Boss Molly (slang for a stubborn female mule). “As a kid growing up in the suburbs in Long Island, that felt special.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: What Is an E-Bike, and How Safe Are They?
description: Surprisingly tricky questions about an increasingly popular vehicle.
content: E-bikes are increasingly visible on roads and bicycle paths, with a growing number of teenagers among the riders. But the recent deaths of several teenage riders have raised concerns about the safety of some types of vehicles, and about whether they legally qualify as e-bikes. Here’s what’s known about e-bikes and their risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Justin Trudeau Hits Reset Button With Major Cabinet Shuffle
description: Canada’s prime minister revamped his cabinet, demoting some ministers and reassigning key portfolios to get in fighting form for an election.
content: As voter frustration boiled because of inflation, housing prices, climate change and other issues, the newly shuffled cabinet of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau posed for a “family photo” on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, July 22-28
description: At minimum, you needed to be familiar with what a quorum was.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: South Africa Blows Another Lead but Collects Its First Point Ever
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 29, 2023
content: “It is fantastic we got our first point, but three would have been better. It’s like you hand me a chocolate and then take it away. And I love chocolate.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: For Luck in Love, Couples Are Breaking Plates (On Purpose)
description: In Germany, smashing porcelain plates is a time-honored wedding custom that is said to bring good fortune and harmony to newlyweds.
content: Weddings are steeped in tradition, but where did those traditions come from? And how do those customs differ in other cultures? In our new column, “Traditions,” we aim to explore the origins of various wedding customs from the United States and around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: In Lessons on Slavery, Context Matters
description: Florida’s history wars are about more than semantics.
content: One of the points I tried to make in my Friday column about the new Florida curriculum on the history of slavery is that the context of a statement can have a radical effect on its meaning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Jennifer Brady, Finally Healthy, Tries to Get Back to Work
description: After a star turn in 2020 and ’21, Brady was sidelined for nearly two years by a chronic foot condition and a knee injury that, combined, sometimes left her in “a very dark place.”
content: Even when the big success finally came, it hardly came easily for Jennifer Brady.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Emile Ducke
title: ‘We Can Never Forgive This’: In Odesa, Attacks Stoke Hatred of Russia
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia views Odesa as a culturally important part of his nation. But many in the Ukrainian city reject the connection and view the country that has been attacking it with loathing.
content: Standing on a bridge overlooking the road to Odesa’s main port, Nina Sulzhenko surveyed the damage wrought by a recent Russian missile strike: The House of Scientists, one of the Ukrainian city’s best-loved buildings, was in shambles. The mansion’s destroyed gardens spilled down over a ruined residential complex, and burned bricks lay strewn across the sidewalk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: With DeSantis Reeling, What About Tim Scott?
description: There’s plenty to say for Scott — but his strengths are also connected to primary-campaign weaknesses.
content: Last Sunday, I argued that despite his stagnation in the polls, for Republicans (and non-Republicans) who would prefer that Donald Trump not be renominated for the presidency, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida remains pretty much the only possible alternative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher
title: $60 Million Refund Request Shows Financial Pressure on Trump From Legal Fees
description: The situation signals a potential money crisis as the former president runs a campaign while under indictment in two jurisdictions and, soon, potentially a third.
content: The political action committee that former President Donald J. Trump is using to pay his legal bills faced such staggering costs this year that it requested a refund on a $60 million contribution it made to another group supporting the Republican front-runner, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald, Matt Joycey and Ben Laffin
title: ‘Evacuated for the Fifth Time’: Worst Wildfires in Canadian History Persist
description: Wildfires in Canada have forced the displacement of thousands of residents. In Northern Quebec, evacuees from the Cree Nation recently returned home after the smoke cleared, only to evacuate yet again after the fires reignited days later.
content: Wildfires in Canada have forced the displacement of thousands of residents. In Northern Quebec, evacuees from the Cree Nation recently returned home after the smoke cleared, only to evacuate yet again after the fires reignited days later.
source.name: The New York Times
